awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP: Constitutional Rights, Judicial Independence and the Transition to Democracy; November 13-16, 2014, -New York Law School
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will bring together a diverse international and interdisciplinary group of practitioners, scholars in both law and social science, and innovative law teachers with expertise in the processes of transition to democracy; globalization and law; the role of constitutional courts; law and social movements; legal pluralism and customary law; economic and social rights; and the impact of legal education on legal professions and law.  Its broader impacts include fostering deeper connections between American and South African scholars, assisting South African lawyers and social scientists in protecting human rights, and building awareness in the United States both of the challenges South Africa faces and of the contributions to democratic and legal thinking that it is making. 

The workshop will be a sustained series of structured discussions around five core themes: judicial independence; the potential, limits and pitfalls of judicial intervention; culture, tradition, public resistance and elite pressure in the assertion of rights; public interest law; and socioeconomic rights and restitution. Papers will be submitted in advance and made available to other presenters on a workshop website, which will also serve as a resource for additional relevant readings and materials. Each theme will be introduced with a plenary session, followed by small-group meetings around particular issues bearing on that theme, and culminating in a report-back session.  Summaries of each session's discussions will be posted on the workshop website. Panels will be designed to bring together socio-legal and legal scholars, legal educators, and practitioners.  It will include participants who are from under-represented groups and who are early-career scholars and students.

por.por_cntn:
During the 2015-16 grant year the New York Law School Law Review published two issues containing 20 articles by South African and American scholars growing out of the November 2014 Workshop on “Constitutional Rights, Judicial Independence and the Transition to Democracy: Twenty Years of South African Constitutionalism,” which NSF Award #1423564 supported. 13 of the 24 authors were women, and approximately 9 of the 24 were South African or American writers of color.  The Law Review students also produced four videos, each 10-15 minutes in length, based on interviews with approximately 30 of the Workshop participants. All of these materials are now available for reading (online and in print) and for viewing online. These publications substantially extended the visibility of the work of the participants in the 2014 Workshop, and attest to the intellectual merit of the scholarly inquiries the Workshop embraced. 

We have continued to look for ways to build on the Workshop to create an ongoing legal education dialogue involving US and South African faculty. A meeting for that purpose was scheduled for January 26, 2016 in Cape Town; unfortunately it had to be cancelled because in November 2015 Professor Stephen Ellmann, the PI, was diagnosed with bile-duct cancer. 

During the 2016-17 grant year, however, Professor Ellmann continued consultations about ways to create this dialogue. We have now formulated a proposal which has the support of both Dean Anthony Crowell of New York Law School and of Dean Penelope Andrews of the University of Cape Town (South Africa) Law Faculty. (Dean Andrews and Professor Ellmann had also worked together on the planning of the 2014 Workshop.) This proposal would initiate a fellowship program for South African clinical/experiential legal educators, through which a South African law teacher would come to New York Law School each January to encounter the wide range of education focused on lawyering skills – through clinics, externships, simulations and other programs – that the school offers. 

We believe that this program will be of value both in assisting South African law teachers as they develop their own pedagogies, and in building ongoing connections and understanding between South African and United States legal academics. The 2014 Workshop aimed both to assess the capacity of law to contribute to building an egalitarian, free society in South Africa (and by implication elsewhere), and to address the crucial question of how law schools can prepare future lawyers for the kinds of lawyering practice that will implement scholarly insights into the role of law in social change. The fellowship program will speak to both of these objectives, and most directly to the critical question – if anything more pressing in South Africa now than it was in 2014 – of the contribution that law schools and law teachers can make to positive social change. In doing so this program will extend the broader impacts of the 2014 Workshop.   

Since we have been notified that the fellowship program would amount to a change in scope from the original grant, we plan to apply for NSF approval for this change, and (provided it is approved) to develop the plans for the fellowships to begin operation. We anticipate that the first fellow would come to New York Law School in January 2019.

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2017
Modified by: Stephen Ellmann
